messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the past 200 years, new machines and better health helped people. So, fewer children died when they were young. The number of people grew fast. Families had many children. These children grew up. Then they had their own children.

Contraception is a way to stop a woman from having a baby. In the 1960s, it was easier to get contraception. So, the normal number of babies for each woman went down. It went from six babies to two babies.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6589 is significantly below the required 0.75. The core message of the original text describes a demographic transition: an initial period of rapid population growth followed by a decline in birth rates. Your version presents these as two separate sets of facts without adequately conveying the crucial 'but' or 'however' that signals the shift and contrast in the original narrative. The separation into two distinct paragraphs without a strong connective loses the overarching meaning of a continuous, evolving demographic trend. Suggestion: Rephrase to explicitly connect the two phases of population change, emphasizing the contrast or shift in trends.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the past 200 years, new machines and better health helped people. So, fewer children died when they were young. The number of people grew fast. Families had many children. These children grew up and had their own children. But later, in the 1960s, contraception became easier to get. Contraception is a way to stop a woman from having a baby. So, the number of babies for each woman went down. It went from six babies to two babies.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6369 is too low, falling below the required 0.75. The original text clearly explains that fewer child deaths 'fuelling rapid population growth' and that 'These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children', establishing a continuous, self-reinforcing cycle of population increase. Your version separates these ideas into discrete facts ('The number of people grew fast. Families had many children. These children grew up and had their own children.'), which loses the crucial causal connection and the self-reinforcing nature of the population growth described in the original. The concept of the growth being 'fueled' by the survival of children from large families is not adequately conveyed, leading to a significant loss of the core message's nuance. Suggestion: Rephrase the section on population growth to explicitly link the survival of children from large families to the ongoing rapid increase in population, ensuring the causal relationship is clear.

Text saved: In the past 200 years, new machines and better health helped people. So, fewer children died when they were young. This made the number of people grow fast. Families had many children. These children grew up and had their own children. This made the number of people grow even more. But later, in the 1960s, contraception became easier to get. Contraception is a way to stop a woman from having a baby. So, the number of babies for each woman went down. It went from six babies to two babies.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5853 is significantly below the required 0.75. The core message of the original text, which details the causal chain of population growth and subsequent decline, has been fragmented and diluted. The original text clearly links 'improvements in technology and health' to 'fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth' and then 'wider availability of contraception' to the 'decline from six babies per woman to as low as two'. Your version breaks these causal relationships into overly simplistic, disconnected sentences, losing the nuanced flow and the direct impact of the factors. For example, the phrase 'fuelling rapid population growth' is weakened by being split into multiple sentences, and the concept of 'global average' is entirely lost. Suggestion: Rephrase to maintain the causal connections and the overall narrative coherence while using A2 vocabulary and sentence structures. Ensure that the cause-and-effect relationships are clear and not fragmented.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the past 200 years, new machines and better health helped people. Fewer children died when they were young. Because of this, the number of people grew fast. Many children grew up and had their own children. So, the number of people grew even more.
Contraception is a way to stop a woman from having a baby. In the 1960s, contraception became easier to get. So, the number of babies for each woman went down. Around the world, it went from six babies to two babies.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6331 is significantly below the required 0.75. While the facts are present, the core message regarding the magnitude and contrast of population changes is diminished. The original text emphasizes the significant decline with 'as low as two' and uses 'But' to clearly mark the shift from growth to decline. Your version loses this emphasis and the strong contrasting conjunction. Suggestion: Rephrase the decline to emphasize its significance. Reintroduce a contrasting conjunction to connect the two main ideas of population growth and decline.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the past 200 years, new machines and better health helped people. Fewer children died when they were young. So, families became big. These big families had many more children. These children also grew up and had their own children. This made the number of people grow very fast.
Contraception is a way to stop a woman from having a baby. But in the 1960s, contraception became easier to get. So, the number of babies for each woman went down a lot. Around the world, it went from six babies to only two babies.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6084 is significantly below the required 0.75. The core message of the original text, which describes a shift from rapid population growth to a decline in birth rates due to contraception, is not fully preserved. The original text uses 'But with the wider availability of contraception...' to clearly signal a counter-trend to the earlier population growth. Your version separates the explanation of population growth from the effect of contraception, introducing the definition of contraception in between. This breaks the logical flow and weakens the causal link between contraception and the *reversal* of the population trend, making the decline appear as a separate event rather than a direct counterpoint to the earlier growth. The nuance of the population dynamics shift is lost. Suggestion: Rephrase to maintain the clear contrast and causal relationship between the initial population growth and the subsequent decline due to contraception, as presented in the original text.
